content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student wishes to determine the concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student combines <math alttext="10.00 milliliters " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with excess <math alttext="N a 2 S O 4, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and observes the formation of a white precipitate. The formation of the precipitate is represented by the following equation.

<math alttext="2 A g N O 3, aqueous, plus N a 2 S O 4, aqueous, react to produce A g 2 S O 4, solid, plus 2 N a N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>A</mtext><msub><mtext>gNO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>Na</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mtext>NaNO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></math>

(a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the precipitation reaction.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student wishes to determine the concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student combines <math alttext="10.00 milliliters " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with excess <math alttext="N a 2 S O 4, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and observes the formation of a white precipitate. The formation of the precipitate is represented by the following equation.

<math alttext="2 A g N O 3, aqueous, plus N a 2 S O 4, aqueous, react to produce A g 2 S O 4, solid, plus 2 N a N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>A</mtext><msub><mtext>gNO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>Na</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mtext>NaNO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></math>

(a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the precipitation reaction.

The student collects the precipitate by filtration and measures the mass of the filter paper and precipitate every <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes as it dries. The student records the data in the following table.

Mass of dry filter paper
 <math alttext="0.88 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.88</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of filter paper and precipitate immediately after filtration
 <math alttext="4.82 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.82</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of filter paper and precipitate after <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes
 <math alttext="4.37 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.37</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of filter paper and precipitate after <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes
 <math alttext="4.01 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.01</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of filter paper and precipitate after <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes
 <math alttext="3.79 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.79</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Use the data above to calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="A g 2 S O 4, solid " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="311.8 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>311.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that precipitated.

(c) Calculate the concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the original <math alttext="10.00 milliliter " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> determined by the student is significantly higher than the actual concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the student’s data table, identify an error in the experimental procedure that led to this result.

skill.text: 2.E: Identify or describe potential sources of experimental error.
